abstract.text: A container for texture data allowing you to create and update textures using your own format.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Use
when you want to bring your own texture data to RealityKit, or update your data frequently.
You update the data on the GPU with Metal compute shaders.
This is ideal for bringing your own textures to RealityKit as-is, or when you intend to update your data frequently.
For a simpler alternative, consider creating your
from a
with
, or
Express your texture by creating a
that describes
how the data is laid out, along with the size of the texture.  This descriptor is similar to
To use
, first configure the descriptor with the desired characteristics of your texture.
Then, you can initialize the
from its descriptor and provide it to a
You update the contents of a
on the GPU, using a Metal Command Buffer and Compute Command Encoder.
For example, you can write a compute kernel in Metal Shading Language to generate the color of each pixel:

code: // Compute texture coordinate ranging from 0 to 1 along each axis.
// Compute the color as a linear gradient from top to bottom.
// Specify an opacity of 1 if the pixel is within a circle
// Write the color and opacity to the texture.

inlineContent.text: You can use this compute kernel to populate the

code: // Set up the Metal command queue and compute command encoder,
// Load a Metal compute kernel written in Metal Shading Language,
let computePipelineState = try? device.makeComputePipelineState(function: function) else {
// Set up the Metal compute command encoder with the app's compute kernel.
// This texture will be directly consumed by RealityKit's renderer.
// Note: threadGroupCount and threadGroupSize determined elsewhere.
// End the encoding and commit the command buffer.
// When the command buffer completes, RealityKit automatically applies the changes.

inlineContent.text: To finish, add your
to a
and display it on an

code: // Create the LowLevelTexture and populate it on the GPU.
// Create a TextureResource from the LowLevelTexture.
// Create a material that uses the texture.
// Return an entity of a plane which uses the generated texture.

abstract.text: Simulate and render 3D content for use in your augmented reality apps.
An element of a RealityKit scene to which you attach components that provide
appearance and behavior characteristics for the entity.
A container for texture data allowing you to create and update textures using your own format.
An object that you use to configure new
objects.
The descriptor that you use to initialize the
Creates a low-level texture from a descriptor.
Retrieves the current texture for GPU reading.
Retrieves a Metal texture that your appâ€™s shaders can write to when they run on a GPU.
A type that describes the material aspects of a mesh, like color and
texture.
A representation of a texture.
A drawable associated with a drawable queue
A drawable queue that may be used to update a texture resource dynamically
Describes the texture managed by the drawable queue
Asynchronously creates a cube texture resource from face images.
Asynchronously creates a texture resource from an in-memory Core
Graphics image.
Asynchronously creates a 2D texture array by generating it from images.
Asynchronously creates a 3D texture by generating it from images.
Create a low-level texture and update its pixel data on the GPU to form a dynamic height and normal map.

doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation.title: Creating a dynamic height and normal map with low-level texture

abstract.text: Bring an iOS or iPadOS game to visionOS and enhance it.

doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation.title: Rendering a windowed game in stereo

abstract.text: An object that you use to configure new Metal texture objects.
A bitmap image or image mask.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.

lowleveltexture-circle-unlit.alt: A screenshot of a circle.  The color of the circle is a linear gradient; the top is light blue and the bottom is close to white.
